import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import warnings 
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore") 

surgeries = pd.read_csv("../input/haberman.csv")
surgeries.head(5)

source.00815472:
# seperating data of both status
survivedAbv5 = surgeries.loc[surgeries['status']==1]
survivedBl5 = surgeries.loc[surgeries['status']==2]
source.a769107e:
for idx, feature in enumerate(survivedAbv5.columns[:-1]):
    counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(survivedAbv5[feature], bins=10,density = True)
    pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
    print(pdf);
    print(bin_edges)
    cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
    print(cdf)
    plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf)
    plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf)
    plt.xlabel(feature)
    plt.title(feature + ' PDF, CDF for patients survived more than 5 years after surgery')
    plt.show();
source.04045a96:
for idx, feature in enumerate(survivedBl5.columns[:-1]):

    pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
    print(pdf);
    print(bin_edges)
    cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)

    plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf)
    plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf)
    plt.xlabel(feature)
    plt.title(feature + ' PDF, CDF for patients survived less than 5 years after surgery')

source.140786d1:
for idx, feature in enumerate(surgeries.columns[:-1]):
    sns.boxplot(x='status',y=feature, data=surgeries)
    plt.title('Box plot for '+feature+' vs status')
    plt.show()
source.ec8d6341:
for idx, feature in enumerate(surgeries.columns[:-1]):
    sns.violinplot(x='status',y=feature, data=surgeries)
    plt.title('Violin plot for '+feature+' vs status')
    warnings.filterwarnings("ignore") 
    plt.show()
source.47dff6eb:
## 2 Objective
To predict whether the patient having breast cancer surgery in the future will survive 5+ years after the surgery or not based on patient's age, year of surgery, number of positive axillary nodes detected.
source.ff705a85: There are **306** breast cancer surgeries conducted between 1958 and 1970 at the University of Chicago's Billings Hospital.
source.d5782233:
### Observation
  1. Most of the patients having surgery are aged between 30 to 70.
  2. Patients aged below 40 have more chance of surviving more than 5 years after surgery than patients aged above 40.
source.cb1b323c:
## Conclusion
Success rate of patients who had under gone breast cancer surgery between 1958 and 1970 at the University of Chicago's Billings Hospital is 73.53%. Most of the patients having surgery are aged between 30 to 70. Patients aged below 40 have more chance of surviving more than 5 years after surgery than patients aged above 40. Most of the patients who survived more than 5 years after surgery have 0 to 7 positive axillary nodes. 86% of people who didn't survived more than 5 years have positive axillary nodes ranging from 0 to 11.
83.5% of people who survived more than 5 years have positive axillary nodes less than 5. Patients having surgery between 1959-1963 and 1966-1969 have the sligtly better chance at surviving more than 5 years. Patients having surgery between 1963-1966 have the sligtly lower chance at surviving more than 5 years.
source.a349be25:
There are **3** features : 1)age - Age of the patient when the surgery took place
2)year - year of the surgery
3)nodes - Number of positive axillary nodes detected
**status** is label/class states whether patient survived 5 years+ or the patient died within 5 years
source.82edfd6e:
## Observation from Univariate analysis
  1. Rate of patient surviving 5+ years after surgery is 73.52941176470588%
  2. 97% of people who didn't survived more than 5 years have positive axillary nodes ranging from 0 to 26. (3.2 PDF, CDF)
  3. Density of people who survived more than 5 years after surgery is high between 0 to 7 positive axillary nodes. (3.1 Histograms)
  4. 83.5% of people who survived more than 5 years have positive axillary nodes less than 5. (3.2 PDF, CDF and 3.4 Violin plot)
source.e87d1b88: Data set is Imbalanced because there are almost trice the observations with status "1" compared to status "2" (Which is a good thing because thrice the patients survived 5 years+ after the surgery)
